trans-unit.source: Draw shapes
trans-unit.target: Draw shapes

trans-unit.source: Learn how to draw shapes, such as ellipses, rectangles, polygons, and paths.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to draw shapes, such as ellipses, rectangles, polygons, and paths.

trans-unit.source: The Path class is the way to visualize a fairly complex vector-based drawing language in a XAML UI; for example, you can draw Bezier curves.
trans-unit.target: The Path class is the way to visualize a fairly complex vector-based drawing language in a XAML UI; for example, you can draw Bezier curves.

trans-unit.source: Draw shapes
trans-unit.target: Draw shapes

trans-unit.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
trans-unit.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

trans-unit.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132) \]

trans-unit.source: Important APIs
trans-unit.target: Important APIs

trans-unit.source: Path
trans-unit.target: Path

trans-unit.source: Windows.UI.Xaml.Shapes namespace
trans-unit.target: Windows.UI.Xaml.Shapes namespace

trans-unit.source: Windows.UI.Xaml.Media namespace
trans-unit.target: Windows.UI.Xaml.Media namespace

trans-unit.source: Learn how to draw shapes, such as ellipses, rectangles, polygons, and paths.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to draw shapes, such as ellipses, rectangles, polygons, and paths.

trans-unit.source: The [**Path**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243355) class is the way to visualize a fairly complex vector-based drawing language in a XAML UI; for example, you can draw Bezier curves.
trans-unit.target: The [**Path**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243355) class is the way to visualize a fairly complex vector-based drawing language in a XAML UI; for example, you can draw Bezier curves.

trans-unit.source: Introduction
trans-unit.target: Introduction

trans-unit.source: Two sets of classes define a region of space in XAML UI: [**Shape**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243377) classes and [**Geometry**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR210041) classes.
trans-unit.target: Two sets of classes define a region of space in XAML UI: [**Shape**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243377) classes and [**Geometry**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR210041) classes.

trans-unit.source: The main difference between these classes is that a **Shape** has a brush associated with it and can be rendered to the screen, and a **Geometry** simply defines a region of space and is not rendered unless it helps contribute information to another UI property.
trans-unit.target: The main difference between these classes is that a **Shape** has a brush associated with it and can be rendered to the screen, and a **Geometry** simply defines a region of space and is not rendered unless it helps contribute information to another UI property.

trans-unit.source: You can think of a **Shape** as a [**UIElement**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208911) with its boundary defined by a **Geometry**.
trans-unit.target: You can think of a **Shape** as a [**UIElement**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208911) with its boundary defined by a **Geometry**.

trans-unit.source: This topic covers mainly the **Shape** classes.
trans-unit.target: This topic covers mainly the **Shape** classes.

trans-unit.source: The [**Shape**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243377) classes are [**Line**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243345), [**Ellipse**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243343), [**Rectangle**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243371), [**Polygon**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243359), [**Polyline**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243365), and [**Path**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243355).
trans-unit.target: The [**Shape**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243377) classes are [**Line**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243345), [**Ellipse**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243343), [**Rectangle**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243371), [**Polygon**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243359), [**Polyline**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243365), and [**Path**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243355).

trans-unit.source: **Path** is interesting because it can define an arbitrary geometry, and the [**Geometry**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR210041) class is involved here because that's one way to define the parts of a **Path**.
trans-unit.target: **Path** is interesting because it can define an arbitrary geometry, and the [**Geometry**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR210041) class is involved here because that's one way to define the parts of a **Path**.

trans-unit.source: Fill and Stroke for shapes
trans-unit.target: Fill and Stroke for shapes

trans-unit.source: For a [**Shape**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243377) to render to the app canvas, you must associate a [**Brush**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR228076) with it.
trans-unit.target: For a [**Shape**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243377) to render to the app canvas, you must associate a [**Brush**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR228076) with it.

trans-unit.source: Set the [**Fill**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.fill) property of the **Shape** to the **Brush** you want.
trans-unit.target: Set the [**Fill**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.fill) property of the **Shape** to the **Brush** you want.

trans-unit.source: For more info about brushes, see [Using brushes](using-brushes.md).
trans-unit.target: For more info about brushes, see [Using brushes](using-brushes.md).

trans-unit.source: A [**Shape**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243377) can also have a [**Stroke**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.stroke), which is a line that is drawn around the shape's perimeter.
trans-unit.target: A [**Shape**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243377) can also have a [**Stroke**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.stroke), which is a line that is drawn around the shape's perimeter.

trans-unit.source: A **Stroke** also requires a [**Brush**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR228076) that defines its appearance, and should have a non-zero value for [**StrokeThickness**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.strokethickness).
trans-unit.target: A **Stroke** also requires a [**Brush**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR228076) that defines its appearance, and should have a non-zero value for [**StrokeThickness**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.strokethickness).

trans-unit.source: **StrokeThickness** is a property that defines the perimeter's thickness around the shape edge.
trans-unit.target: **StrokeThickness** is a property that defines the perimeter's thickness around the shape edge.

trans-unit.source: If you don't specify a **Brush** value for **Stroke**, or if you set **StrokeThickness** to 0, then the border around the shape is not drawn.
trans-unit.target: If you don't specify a **Brush** value for **Stroke**, or if you set **StrokeThickness** to 0, then the border around the shape is not drawn.

trans-unit.source: Ellipse
trans-unit.target: Ellipse

trans-unit.source: An [**Ellipse**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243343) is a shape with a curved perimeter.
trans-unit.target: An [**Ellipse**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243343) is a shape with a curved perimeter.

trans-unit.source: To create a basic **Ellipse**, specify a [**Width**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208751), [**Height**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208718), and a [**Brush**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR228076) for the [**Fill**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.fill).
trans-unit.target: To create a basic **Ellipse**, specify a [**Width**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208751), [**Height**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208718), and a [**Brush**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR228076) for the [**Fill**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.fill).

trans-unit.source: The next example creates an [**Ellipse**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243343) with a [**Width**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208751) of 200 and a [**Height**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208718) of 200, and uses a [**SteelBlue**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/Hh748056) colored [**SolidColorBrush**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242962) as its [**Fill**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.fill).
trans-unit.target: The next example creates an [**Ellipse**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243343) with a [**Width**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208751) of 200 and a [**Height**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208718) of 200, and uses a [**SteelBlue**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/Hh748056) colored [**SolidColorBrush**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242962) as its [**Fill**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.fill).

trans-unit.source: Here's the rendered [**Ellipse**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243343).
trans-unit.target: Here's the rendered [**Ellipse**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243343).

trans-unit.source: A rendered Ellipse.
trans-unit.target: A rendered Ellipse.

trans-unit.source: In this case the [**Ellipse**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243343) is what most people would consider a circle, but that's how you declare a circle shape in XAML: use an **Ellipse** with equal [**Width**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208751) and [**Height**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208718).
trans-unit.target: In this case the [**Ellipse**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243343) is what most people would consider a circle, but that's how you declare a circle shape in XAML: use an **Ellipse** with equal [**Width**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208751) and [**Height**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208718).

trans-unit.source: When an [**Ellipse**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243343) is positioned in a UI layout, its size is assumed to be the same as a rectangle with that [**Width**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208751) and [**Height**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208718); the area outside the perimeter does not have rendering but still is part of its layout slot size.
trans-unit.target: When an [**Ellipse**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243343) is positioned in a UI layout, its size is assumed to be the same as a rectangle with that [**Width**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208751) and [**Height**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208718); the area outside the perimeter does not have rendering but still is part of its layout slot size.

trans-unit.source: A set of 6 [**Ellipse**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243343) elements are part of the control template for the [**ProgressRing**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR227538) control, and 2 concentric **Ellipse** elements are part of a [**RadioButton**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR227544).
trans-unit.target: A set of 6 [**Ellipse**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243343) elements are part of the control template for the [**ProgressRing**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR227538) control, and 2 concentric **Ellipse** elements are part of a [**RadioButton**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR227544).

trans-unit.source: Rectangle
trans-unit.target: Rectangle

trans-unit.source: A [**Rectangle**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243371) is a four-sided shape with its opposite sides being equal.
trans-unit.target: A [**Rectangle**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243371) is a four-sided shape with its opposite sides being equal.

trans-unit.source: To create a basic **Rectangle**, specify a [**Width**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208751), a [**Height**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208718), and a [**Fill**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.fill).
trans-unit.target: To create a basic **Rectangle**, specify a [**Width**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208751), a [**Height**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208718), and a [**Fill**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.fill).

trans-unit.source: You can round the corners of a [**Rectangle**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243371).
trans-unit.target: You can round the corners of a [**Rectangle**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243371).

trans-unit.source: To create rounded corners, specify a value for the [**RadiusX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.rectangle.radiusx.aspx) and [**RadiusY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.rectangle.radiusy) properties.
trans-unit.target: To create rounded corners, specify a value for the [**RadiusX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.rectangle.radiusx.aspx) and [**RadiusY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.rectangle.radiusy) properties.

trans-unit.source: These properties specify the x-axis and y-axis of an ellipse that defines the curve of the corners.
trans-unit.target: These properties specify the x-axis and y-axis of an ellipse that defines the curve of the corners.

trans-unit.source: The maximum allowed value of **RadiusX** is the [**Width**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208751) divided by two and the maximum allowed value of **RadiusY** is the [**Height**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208718) divided by two.
trans-unit.target: The maximum allowed value of **RadiusX** is the [**Width**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208751) divided by two and the maximum allowed value of **RadiusY** is the [**Height**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208718) divided by two.

trans-unit.source: The next example creates a [**Rectangle**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243371) with a [**Width**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208751) of 200 and a [**Height**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208718) of 100.
trans-unit.target: The next example creates a [**Rectangle**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243371) with a [**Width**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208751) of 200 and a [**Height**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR208718) of 100.

trans-unit.source: It uses a [**Blue**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/Hh747837) value of [**SolidColorBrush**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242962) for its [**Fill**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.fill) and a [**Black**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/Hh747833) value of **SolidColorBrush** for its [**Stroke**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.stroke).
trans-unit.target: It uses a [**Blue**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/Hh747837) value of [**SolidColorBrush**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR242962) for its [**Fill**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.fill) and a [**Black**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/Hh747833) value of **SolidColorBrush** for its [**Stroke**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.stroke).

trans-unit.source: We set the [**StrokeThickness**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.strokethickness) to 3.
trans-unit.target: We set the [**StrokeThickness**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.strokethickness) to 3.

trans-unit.source: We set the [**RadiusX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.rectangle.radiusx.aspx) property to 50 and the [**RadiusY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.rectangle.radiusy) property to 10, which gives the **Rectangle** rounded corners.
trans-unit.target: We set the [**RadiusX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.rectangle.radiusx.aspx) property to 50 and the [**RadiusY**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.rectangle.radiusy) property to 10, which gives the **Rectangle** rounded corners.

trans-unit.source: Here's the rendered [**Polygon**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243359).
trans-unit.target: Here's the rendered [**Polygon**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243359).

trans-unit.source: A rendered Polygon.
trans-unit.target: A rendered Polygon.

trans-unit.source: **Tip** A [**Point**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR225870) value is often used as a type in XAML for scenarios other than declaring the vertices of shapes.
trans-unit.target: **Tip** A [**Point**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR225870) value is often used as a type in XAML for scenarios other than declaring the vertices of shapes.

trans-unit.source: For example, a **Point** is part of the event data for touch events, so you can know exactly where in a coordinate space the touch action occurred.
trans-unit.target: For example, a **Point** is part of the event data for touch events, so you can know exactly where in a coordinate space the touch action occurred.

trans-unit.source: For more info about **Point** and how to use it in XAML or code, see the API reference topic for [**Point**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR225870).
trans-unit.target: For more info about **Point** and how to use it in XAML or code, see the API reference topic for [**Point**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR225870).

trans-unit.source: Line
trans-unit.target: Line

trans-unit.source: A [**Line**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243345) is simply a line drawn between two points in coordinate space.
trans-unit.target: A [**Line**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243345) is simply a line drawn between two points in coordinate space.

trans-unit.source: A **Line** ignores any value provided for [**Fill**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.fill), because it has no interior space.
trans-unit.target: A **Line** ignores any value provided for [**Fill**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.fill), because it has no interior space.

trans-unit.source: For a **Line**, make sure to specify values for the [**Stroke**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.stroke) and [**StrokeThickness**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.strokethickness) properties, because otherwise the **Line** won't render.
trans-unit.target: For a **Line**, make sure to specify values for the [**Stroke**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.stroke) and [**StrokeThickness**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.strokethickness) properties, because otherwise the **Line** won't render.

trans-unit.source: You don't use [**Point**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR225870) values to specify a [**Line**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243345) shape, instead you use discrete [**Double**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/xaml/system.double.aspx) values for [**X1**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.line.x1.aspx), [**Y1**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.line.y1.aspx), [**X2**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.line.x2.aspx) and [**Y2**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.line.y2.aspx).
trans-unit.target: You don't use [**Point**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR225870) values to specify a [**Line**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243345) shape, instead you use discrete [**Double**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/xaml/system.double.aspx) values for [**X1**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.line.x1.aspx), [**Y1**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.line.y1.aspx), [**X2**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.line.x2.aspx) and [**Y2**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.line.y2.aspx).

trans-unit.source: This enables minimal markup for horizontal or vertical lines.
trans-unit.target: This enables minimal markup for horizontal or vertical lines.

trans-unit.source: For example, `<Line Stroke="Red" X2="400"/>` defines a horizontal line that is 400 pixels long.
trans-unit.target: For example, `<Line Stroke="Red" X2="400"/>` defines a horizontal line that is 400 pixels long.

trans-unit.source: The other X,Y properties are 0 by default, so in terms of points this XAML would draw a line from `(0,0)` to `(400,0)`.
trans-unit.target: The other X,Y properties are 0 by default, so in terms of points this XAML would draw a line from `(0,0)` to `(400,0)`.

trans-unit.source: You could then use a [**TranslateTransform**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243027) to move the entire **Line**, if you wanted it to start at a point other than (0,0).
trans-unit.target: You could then use a [**TranslateTransform**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243027) to move the entire **Line**, if you wanted it to start at a point other than (0,0).

trans-unit.source: Polyline
trans-unit.target: Polyline

trans-unit.source: A [**Polyline**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243365) is similar to a [**Polygon**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243359) in that the boundary of the shape is defined by a set of points, except the last point in a **Polyline** is not connected to the first point.
trans-unit.target: A [**Polyline**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243365) is similar to a [**Polygon**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243359) in that the boundary of the shape is defined by a set of points, except the last point in a **Polyline** is not connected to the first point.

trans-unit.source: **Note** You could explicitly have an identical start point and end point in the [**Points**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.polyline.points.aspx) set for the [**Polyline**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243365), but in that case you probably could have used a [**Polygon**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243359) instead.
trans-unit.target: **Note** You could explicitly have an identical start point and end point in the [**Points**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.polyline.points.aspx) set for the [**Polyline**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243365), but in that case you probably could have used a [**Polygon**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243359) instead.

trans-unit.source: If you specify a [**Fill**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.fill) of a [**Polyline**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243365), the **Fill** paints the interior space of the shape, even if the start point and end point of the [**Points**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.polyline.points.aspx) set for the **Polyline** do not intersect.
trans-unit.target: If you specify a [**Fill**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.fill) of a [**Polyline**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243365), the **Fill** paints the interior space of the shape, even if the start point and end point of the [**Points**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.polyline.points.aspx) set for the **Polyline** do not intersect.

trans-unit.source: If you do not specify a **Fill**, then the **Polyline** is similar to what would have rendered if you had specified several individual [**Line**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243345) elements where the start points and end points of consecutive lines intersected.
trans-unit.target: If you do not specify a **Fill**, then the **Polyline** is similar to what would have rendered if you had specified several individual [**Line**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243345) elements where the start points and end points of consecutive lines intersected.

trans-unit.source: As with a [**Polygon**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243359), the [**Points**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.polyline.points.aspx) property defines the collection of points that make up the boundary.
trans-unit.target: As with a [**Polygon**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243359), the [**Points**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.polyline.points.aspx) property defines the collection of points that make up the boundary.

trans-unit.source: In XAML, you define the points with a comma-separated list.
trans-unit.target: In XAML, you define the points with a comma-separated list.

trans-unit.source: In code-behind, you use a [**PointCollection**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR210220) to define the points and you add each individual point as a [**Point**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR225870) structure to the collection.
trans-unit.target: In code-behind, you use a [**PointCollection**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR210220) to define the points and you add each individual point as a [**Point**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR225870) structure to the collection.

trans-unit.source: This example creates a [**Polyline**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243365) with four points set to `(10,200)`, `(60,140)`, `(130,140)`, and `(180,200)`.
trans-unit.target: This example creates a [**Polyline**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243365) with four points set to `(10,200)`, `(60,140)`, `(130,140)`, and `(180,200)`.

trans-unit.source: A [**Stroke**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.stroke) is defined but not a [**Fill**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.fill).
trans-unit.target: A [**Stroke**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.stroke) is defined but not a [**Fill**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.fill).

trans-unit.source: Here's the rendered [**Polyline**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243365).
trans-unit.target: Here's the rendered [**Polyline**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243365).

trans-unit.source: Notice that the first and last points are not connected by the [**Stroke**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.stroke) outline as they are in a [**Polygon**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243359).
trans-unit.target: Notice that the first and last points are not connected by the [**Stroke**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.shape.stroke) outline as they are in a [**Polygon**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243359).

trans-unit.source: A rendered Polyline.
trans-unit.target: A rendered Polyline.

trans-unit.source: Path
trans-unit.target: Path

trans-unit.source: A [**Path**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243355) is the most versatile [**Shape**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243377) because you can use it to define an arbitrary geometry.
trans-unit.target: A [**Path**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243355) is the most versatile [**Shape**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243377) because you can use it to define an arbitrary geometry.

trans-unit.source: But with this versatility comes complexity.
trans-unit.target: But with this versatility comes complexity.

trans-unit.source: Let's now look at how to create a basic **Path** in XAML.
trans-unit.target: Let's now look at how to create a basic **Path** in XAML.

trans-unit.source: You define the geometry of a path with the [**Data**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.path.data) property.
trans-unit.target: You define the geometry of a path with the [**Data**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.path.data) property.

trans-unit.source: There are two techniques for setting **Data**:
trans-unit.target: There are two techniques for setting **Data**:

trans-unit.source: You can set a string value for [**Data**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.path.data) in XAML.
trans-unit.target: You can set a string value for [**Data**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.path.data) in XAML.

trans-unit.source: In this form, the **Path.Data** value is consuming a serialization format for graphics.
trans-unit.target: In this form, the **Path.Data** value is consuming a serialization format for graphics.

trans-unit.source: You typically don't text-edit this value in string form after it is first established.
trans-unit.target: You typically don't text-edit this value in string form after it is first established.

trans-unit.source: Instead, you use design tools that enable you to work in a design or drawing metaphor on a surface.
trans-unit.target: Instead, you use design tools that enable you to work in a design or drawing metaphor on a surface.

trans-unit.source: Then you save or export the output, and this gives you a XAML file or XAML string fragment with **Path.Data** information.
trans-unit.target: Then you save or export the output, and this gives you a XAML file or XAML string fragment with **Path.Data** information.

trans-unit.source: You can set the [**Data**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.path.data) property to a single [**Geometry**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR210041) object.
trans-unit.target: You can set the [**Data**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.path.data) property to a single [**Geometry**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR210041) object.

trans-unit.source: This can be done in code or in XAML.
trans-unit.target: This can be done in code or in XAML.

trans-unit.source: That single **Geometry** is typically a [**GeometryGroup**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR210041group), which acts as a container that can composite multiple geometry definitions into a single object for purposes of the object model.
trans-unit.target: That single **Geometry** is typically a [**GeometryGroup**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR210041group), which acts as a container that can composite multiple geometry definitions into a single object for purposes of the object model.

trans-unit.source: The most common reason for doing this is because you want to use one or more of the curves and complex shapes that can be defined as [**Segments**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR210164) values for a [**PathFigure**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR210143), for example [**BezierSegment**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR228068).
trans-unit.target: The most common reason for doing this is because you want to use one or more of the curves and complex shapes that can be defined as [**Segments**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR210164) values for a [**PathFigure**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR210143), for example [**BezierSegment**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR228068).

trans-unit.source: This example shows a [**Path**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243355) that might have resulted from using Blend for Visual Studio to produce just a few vector shapes and then saving the result as XAML.
trans-unit.target: This example shows a [**Path**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR243355) that might have resulted from using Blend for Visual Studio to produce just a few vector shapes and then saving the result as XAML.

trans-unit.source: The total **Path** consists of a Bezier curve segment and a line segment.
trans-unit.target: The total **Path** consists of a Bezier curve segment and a line segment.

trans-unit.source: The example is mainly intended to give you some examples of what elements exist in the [**Path.Data**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.path.data) serialization format and what the numbers represent.
trans-unit.target: The example is mainly intended to give you some examples of what elements exist in the [**Path.Data**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.path.data) serialization format and what the numbers represent.

trans-unit.source: This [**Data**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.path.data) begins with the move command, indicated by "M", which establishes an absolute start point for the path.
trans-unit.target: This [**Data**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.path.data) begins with the move command, indicated by "M", which establishes an absolute start point for the path.

trans-unit.source: The first segment is a cubic Bezier curve that begins at `(100,200)` and ends at `(400,175)`, which is drawn by using the two control points `(100,25)` and `(400,350)`.
trans-unit.target: The first segment is a cubic Bezier curve that begins at `(100,200)` and ends at `(400,175)`, which is drawn by using the two control points `(100,25)` and `(400,350)`.

trans-unit.source: This segment is indicated by the "C" command in the [**Data**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.path.data) attribute string.
trans-unit.target: This segment is indicated by the "C" command in the [**Data**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.path.data) attribute string.

trans-unit.source: The second segment begins with an absolute horizontal line command "H", which specifies a line drawn from the preceding subpath endpoint `(400,175)` to a new endpoint `(280,175)`.
trans-unit.target: The second segment begins with an absolute horizontal line command "H", which specifies a line drawn from the preceding subpath endpoint `(400,175)` to a new endpoint `(280,175)`.

trans-unit.source: Because it's a horizontal line command, the value specified is an x-coordinate.
trans-unit.target: Because it's a horizontal line command, the value specified is an x-coordinate.

trans-unit.source: One reason you might use [**PathGeometry**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR210168) with the various parts is that each of the parts has **Double** and **Point** properties that you potentially could target for a UI animation.
trans-unit.target: One reason you might use [**PathGeometry**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR210168) with the various parts is that each of the parts has **Double** and **Point** properties that you potentially could target for a UI animation.

trans-unit.source: You can't do that with the serialization form of [**Path.Data**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.path.data).
trans-unit.target: You can't do that with the serialization form of [**Path.Data**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/windows.ui.xaml.shapes.path.data).

trans-unit.source: For more info, see [Storyboarded animations](storyboarded-animations.md).
trans-unit.target: For more info, see [Storyboarded animations](storyboarded-animations.md).
